awd_abstract_narration:
This Faculty Early Career Development (CAREER) award will facilitate novel, operationally aware design of matching markets, such as online marketplaces for transportation and accommodations, collaborative consumption, labor, and school admissions.  Matching markets allow compatible agents to match with each other for mutual benefit. Facilitating efficient marketplaces for matching requires a design approach that carefully manages the costs and benefits to participants of searching for and forming a match, as well as balancing supply and demand. This grant will contribute to the U. S. and global economy and society by enabling design of improved, "smart" marketplaces that better enable participants in the sharing economy to find what they want. The research conducted will be interdisciplinary, involving key ideas from operations, engineering, economics and business practice. This interdisciplinary approach will lead to new intellectual developments and facilitate training of a new breed of market engineers who will design the sharing economy of the future.  The educational plan involves integration of research and practical developments from new marketplaces into online and widely disseminated course materials.

The research plan has three main objectives. First, it will develop a general framework for understanding how a matching platform should best enable search for partners, as a function of market characteristics, motivated by the widespread difficulty faced by users in finding a suitable partner in many markets. Second, it will address the problem of matching when supply and demand are geographically and temporally distributed and the cost of a match increases with geographical separation between the agents, as is the case, for instance, in transportation markets.  The research will leverage tools from optimal transport and queuing networks to support platform decisions on how to match agents and optimally deploy levers like pricing and recommendations to participants, to balance supply and demand and to keep costs of matching low. Third, it will extend existing mechanisms  for centralized school choice and college admissions programs to effectively reassign seats when an assigned seat is vacated at a late stage in the process.  Such reassignments must manage the tradeoff between the economic properties of the process design and the operational costs associated with churn resulting from reassignment.

por.por_cntn:
This project studied the design and operations of two-sided matching marketplaces, including both centralized clearinghouses (e.g., a unified portal for public engineering college admissions in India, where applicants are matched to programs) as well as online platforms for services like Upwork (a labor market where freelancers match with clients), Airbnb, and others. It produced research output, summarized below, in each of three streams, which is influencing the development of the several academic literature(s), as well as related practical applications. It also provided training and development opportunities for several graduate students. It enabled the creation of teaching material for graduate students, including the material for a PhD class on marketplaces taught at Columbia, and papers taught at peer universities such as NYU and Stanford.

The first research stream produced foundational design insights for enabling the search for partners in matching platforms, for example, answering the question of which user should be the one to initiate contact in order to generate a match between a pair of users. A particular finding is that the user who is more selective should be the one to reach out, if they are interested. For example, in Airbnb, guests are more selective, and they are the ones to screen properties and apply to or book their chosen property. In addition to such strategic design, this stream of work has produced algorithmic insights for partner recommendations and centralized matches, and a theoretical paper which augments statistical physics methodologies to understand market “congestion”, i.e., difficulty clearing matching markets. A paper from this stream was the Lead Article in an issue of the prestigious journal, Management Science. This research has attracted interest from and been presented at some of the leading online marketplace firms such as Airbnb and Thumbtack.

The second stream tackled the challenge of matching when supply and demand are geographically and temporally spread out, and when matching costs rise with the distance between agents, such as in the ride-hailing market. It generated new, broadly applicable algorithms for matching demand which arrives over time: (i) The “Mirror Backpressure” algorithm for dynamic resource allocation (e.g., matching of customers with vehicles in settings such as ridehailing) which protects or enhances scarce resources as it matches. The Mirror Backpressure algorithm is already entered use in major real-world applications, including for budget management in online advertising campaigns (e.g., at Google), and for rapidly solving large resource allocation problems which involve a number of “microdecisions” (e.g., assignment of customer shipments to paths in a supply chain), each of which consume only a small amount of resources. (ii) The Simulate-Optimize-Assign-Repeat (SOAR) algorithm for forward-looking dynamic matching in “spatial” settings such as home services marketplaces where service providers and customers both inhabit some “space” such as geographical space. SOAR forms matches by repeatedly using a simulation future demand to enable a forward-looking choice of match. (iii) The Repeatedly Act based on Multiple Simulations (RAMS) algorithm, a unifying and practical forward-looking algorithm for the broad class of dynamic resource allocation problems with many types, for example order fulfillment in e-commerce, with thousands of customer zip codes. RAMS is conceptually similar to SOAR except that it leverages multiple simulations of future demand. It recovers or beats state-of-the-art performance for a large swathe of dynamic resource allocation settings, and moreover is simple and practical. Finally, in this stream we also developed foundational theory regarding unavoidable costs in different settings where demand and supply live in a multidimensional space and need to be matched over time with each other.

The third stream addressed centralized school choice programs and college admissions which match applicants to programs via a single clearinghouse for applicant preference rankings and program rankings of applicants. A specific focus was mitigating inefficiencies caused by applicants accepting a seat only to later vacate it. One project implemented and studied a new large-scale centralized seat allocation process in India for public engineering colleges, with tens of thousands of seats, overcoming challenges including one of the most complex affirmative action programs in the world. The project was selected as a finalist for the 2018 Wagner Prize for Excellence in Operations Research Practice. Innovations to improve utilization of seats included centralization, multiple rounds of admissions in order to fill seats which were not accepted/vacated by those they were previously assigned to, and giving applicants the ability to release a seat that they had previously accepted, leading to a reduction in vacancies at the prestigious Indian Institutes of Technology by 70%. Another project conducted a theoretical analysis to discover a principled and practical mechanism for reallocating vacated seats in the context of school admissions.

Research under this grant was conducted in collaboration with peers from institutions such as Stanford, USC, Princeton, and IIT Bombay, and has been disseminated widely via seminars and publications.
